(23) In a foreign country, there was a dragon-taming master who filled a water basin, went to the edge of a dragon pond, and single-mindedly recited a spell. The dragon immediately saw a great fire rising from the bottom of the pond, burning the entire pond.

The dragon, frightened by the fire, raised its head to look at the mountains, but saw the great fire burning all the mountains and marshes. Looking up at the mountain peaks, there was nowhere to stay, all of it hot. The only place to rest was in the water in the water basin, so it extinguished its huge body, made it very small, and entered the water in the water basin.

The dragon pond is a metaphor for the desire realm, the mountains and marshes it looks up to are a metaphor for the form realm, looking at the mountain peak is a metaphor for the formless realm, the dragon-taming master is a metaphor for the bodhisattva, the water in the bathing jar is a metaphor for nirvana, the technique is a metaphor for skillful means, the great burning fire is a metaphor for manifesting impermanence, the dragon's great body is a metaphor for arrogance, and the small form it makes is a metaphor for humility.

It is said that the bodhisattva manifests the burning of the kalpa, with the desire and form realms burning together, the great fire of impermanence terrifying sentient beings, causing them to remove arrogance and be humble, and only then does he completely enter nirvana.

(24) In the past, a bird catcher set a net on a marsh, with the food birds eat placed inside. Many birds came to eat it, and the bird catcher pulled the net, causing all the birds to fall into the net.
At that time, there was a large bird with great strength. It lifted the net and flew away with the crowd. The bird catcher saw its shadow and chased after it.
Someone said to the bird catcher:
The bird flies in the sky and you walk to chase it. How foolish!
The bird catcher replied:
It is not as you say. When the bird reaches dusk, it will seek a place to roost. Its direction will be different. It will fall like this.

The man still chased after it without stopping. The sun had already turned to dusk. He looked up and saw the many birds flying and struggling, wanting to go east or west, hoping for a long forest or rushing to a stream. Struggling without stopping, they fell in an instant. The bird catcher got them back and killed them in order.
The bird catcher is like PÄpÄ«yÄn;
The spread net is like the afflictions;
Carrying the net and flying is like a person who has not yet left the afflictions and wants to seek the essential path;
Stopping at dusk is like a lazy person who does not continue to make progress;
Those who seek shelter differently are like those who give rise to the sixty-two views and contradict each other;
The bird that falls to the ground is like a person who receives an evil retribution and falls into hell.
This clarifies the dust and dirt of afflictions and the net of demons. Therefore, afflictions cover people like a net.
In the two paths, one should be good and protect one's body and speech well, not allowing oneself to be negligent and caught in this net.
The suffering of the three evil paths and the long-lasting cycle of birth and death are unbearable.

(25) In the past, there were five hundred merchants who sailed on a ship into the ocean to seek precious treasures. They encountered a giant makara fish that emerged, opened its mouth, and wanted to eat the beings.
At that time, the wind was favorable and the ship went as fast as an arrow. The captain said to the people,
The ship is going too fast. Let's lower the sails and drift.
They immediately did as he said, lowered the sails and drifted, but the ship still went very fast and could not be stopped.
The caravan leader asked the people on the boat:
What did you see?
They replied:
We saw two suns rising above, white mountains below the sun, and a black mountain in between.
The caravan leader exclaimed in alarm:
This is a huge fish! What should we do?
We and you are now in a difficult situation. Entering the belly of this fish, there is no way to revive. Each of you should seek salvation with single-minded devotion to your respective deities.
Then the people each followed their respective deities, with single-minded devotion, seeking to escape this calamity.
The more they sought, the more urgent they became, and the boat went faster and faster, without stopping for a moment, heading straight for the fish's mouth.
Then the caravan leader told the people:
I have a great deity named Buddha. Each of you should abandon what you are holding and single-mindedly chant his name!
At that time, the five hundred people all shouted loudly, chanting:
Homage to the Buddha!
The fish heard the Buddha's name and thought to itself:
Today, the world has a Buddha again. How can I bear to harm sentient beings again?
As soon as he had this thought, he immediately closed his mouth, and the water flowed back, turning far away from the fish's mouth. The five hundred merchants were all saved from danger.

This fish had previously been a monk in a past life, but due to a minor offense, it received the form of a fish. Having heard the Buddha's voice, it immediately remembered its past life, and therefore had wholesome thoughts and a good mind arose.

This clarifies that the five hundred merchants only single-mindedly thought of the Buddha, and by briefly chanting his name, they immediately gained liberation from the calamity of being swallowed by the whale. How much more so for those who uphold the samadhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, enabling heavy offenses to become light, and light ones to be extinguished. This can be taken as evidence.
(26) In the past, there was a butcher who went to King Ajatashatru and asked for a single wish.
The king said:
What wish do you seek?
He replied:
On festive occasions, it is necessary to slaughter. The king has granted me this, and I will do it all.
The king said:
The business of slaughtering is what people do not enjoy. Why do you enjoy seeking it?
He replied:

I was formerly a poor man. Because of slaughtering sheep for a living, I was able to be reborn in the Heaven of the Four Kings. After exhausting the lifespan of that heaven, I was reborn among humans and continued to slaughter sheep. After death, I was reborn in the second heaven above;
In this way, I slaughtered sheep six times, and because of this, I was reborn in all six heavens, receiving immeasurable blessings. For this reason, I now beg for a single wish from the king.
The king said:
If it is as you say, how can we know?
He replied:
I recognize my past lives.
The king heard this but did not believe it, thinking it was a lie:
How can such a lowly person possibly recognize his past lives?
Later, he asked the Buddha, and the Buddha replied:
It is truly as he says, not a lie!

This person had previously encountered a pratyekabuddha in a past life. Seeing the Buddha, he was delighted and observed him with utmost sincerity. Looking up at his head and down at his feet, a wholesome mind arose. Because of this merit, he was reborn in the heavens six times and in the human realm six times, remembering his past lives. Because his blessings were ripe, he obtained rebirth in the heavens and human realm six times. Because his offenses were not yet ripe, he did not yet experience suffering;
After exhausting this body, he will enter hell to receive the retribution for slaughtering sheep. After completing his offenses in hell, he will be reborn as a sheep to repay each one.

This person's memory of past lives is shallow, only seeing the affairs in the six heavens, not reaching his past seventh life, so he thinks that slaughtering sheep is the cause for rebirth in the heavens.
In this way, he only remembers his past lives, it is not supernormal power or wisdom!
Therefore, those who cultivate merit must make vows, do not be rash and cause their karmic retribution to be unclear. This can be taken as verification!
(27) Ananda said to the Buddha:
The Buddha was born into a royal family, sat under a tree and contemplated the Way for six years, and attained Buddhahood like this, is it easy to attain?
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the past, there was an elder who lived in great wealth and was fully endowed with many treasures, but he lacked red pearls, so he took people into the ocean to collect pearls.

After going through dangers and difficulties, he reached the place of treasures, pierced his body to draw blood, wrapped it in an oil bag and hung it on the bottom of the ocean. The pearl oysters smelled the fragrance of the blood and sucked on it, and then the pearl oysters emerged.

He opened the oysters and obtained the pearls, and after three years of collecting, he obtained one pendant.ğŸ”½When he set out to return to the shore, his companions saw that he had obtained good treasures, and wanted to plot against him. They all went to fetch water together, and the group pushed him into a well and covered it up and left.

He fell to the bottom of the well for a long time. He saw a lion come from a side hole to drink water. The man was frightened again. After the lion left, he followed the hole out and returned to his homeland.
The companion returned home and called out:
You obtained my pearl. No one knows about it and you want to harm me. You should secretly return it to me, and I will never tell on you!
The man, frightened and anxious, returned the pearl in its entirety.
The owner of the pearl took it back home. There were two children who played with the pearl together. They asked each other:
Where did this pearl come from?
One child said:
It came from my bag.
The other child said:
It came from the jar in the room.
The father saw this and laughed. The wife said:
Why are you laughing?
He replied:
I obtained this pearl with great difficulty. The children got it from me, but they don't know its origins and say it came from a jar.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

You only see me attain Buddhahood, but do not know the hardships I have undergone in learning for countless eons. It is only now that I can be called easy, like that infant who thinks the pearl is born in the pouch.
Therefore, cultivating myriad practices, accumulating merits over eons, it is not something that can be attained in just one matter, one practice, or one lifetime!
(28) In the past, there was a guide who entered the ocean to collect treasures. At that time, five hundred people followed him and went together. The guide said to them:
There are five difficulties in the ocean:
First, rushing currents; second, swirling waves; third, giant fish; fourth, female ghosts; fifth, intoxicating fruits.
If you can overcome these difficulties, then you may go together.
After the group made an agreement, they sailed into the ocean and reached Treasure Island. They went separately to collect treasures.
One person could not resist the fragrance of the fruit and ate it. He became intoxicated for seven days.

The people's treasures were sufficient, and the wind had already arrived. They wanted to return and set out, beating the drum to gather the people. One person was missing, and they searched in the four directions.
They saw him lying under a tree, drunk and still not sober. They helped him back together and propped him up with a tree branch. They returned together to the country.
The family heard the news and came out to welcome him. The drunkard saw that he had nothing to gain and was extremely sad.
The drunkard was unhappy and entered the market with his cane. The people in the market asked for a price, up to twenty thousand taels of gold. The man gave it to them and asked:
What virtues does this cane have?
He said:
This is a tree treasure. Pound and burn this cane, and all tiles and stones will become precious treasures.
The man asked for it, took a little back to try it out, and it was indeed as he said. Everything it fumigated became various treasures.
The parable said:
The guide refers to the bodhisattvas;
The five difficulties refer to the five aggregates;
The treasure island refers to the seven riches of prajÃ±Ä.
Drunk means to be lazy and negligent from the mind;
Breaking off a branch of a precious tree means to cultivate and encourage oneself;
Rekindling vigor and transforming tiles and stones into treasures means to use the scriptures and the Way to transform all evil practices into Dharma vessels!
(29) In the past, there were two monks in the mountains, who lived in seclusion and attained the six spiritual powers.
Not far away, there was a lioness who gave birth to two cubs.

As they gradually grew up, the lioness' mother wanted to go away, and she thought, Only the two kinds of kindness of morality and virtue can be entrusted with life, and said, I want to go away, but the two cubs are still young and may be harmed by people. I want to entrust them to the monks.
Please protect them with kindness, and I will come back to see them.
The monks agreed.
The lioness went away and came back, and saw her cubs with the monks. She left again.
The monks returned from alms-round and shared their leftover food with the cubs. Every time they saw the monks return, they would happily go out to greet them.
The practitioner walked away, and the hunter encountered him. The lion cub ran away into the grass. The hunter relied on the practitioner and entered the grass to capture it.
The lion thought it was the practitioner and came out to meet it. The hunter killed it and skinned it to make a lion skin robe, worth a thousand ounces of gold.

The practitioner walked back and did not see the lion. He sat in meditation and observed it, knowing that it had been killed by the hunter. He then used his spiritual powers to take the skin back and made a cushion to sit on. He spoke a mantra and meditated again, knowing that it would be reborn as twin sons in the family of an elder in a certain country.
The practitioner went to the elder's house and asked:
What do you lack?
He said:
I only suffer from having no children.
He then told the elder to seek sons for him.
The elder was overjoyed. The practitioner said:
If you obtain sons, how will you repay me?
He said:ğŸ”½I will give you half of my property.
When the child grows up, he should be given to the Å›ramaá¹‡a as a novice.
The practitioner said:
Do not forget this vow.
Only then did she become pregnant, and later gave birth to twin boys who were similar to each other.
When they were eight or nine years old, the practitioner passed by. The two children naturally rejoiced upon seeing him. The practitioner said to the elder:
Do you remember your original vow?
The elder did not dare go against the vow, so he gave the two sons to the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a took them into the mountains to study. Before long, they also attained arhatship.
They always sat on the original hide. Every day they entered meditation and observed themselves, and then saw their own previous bodies' hides, each of them arose and expressed gratitude, saying:
By the power of the teacher's kindness, we have attained the Way. It is all due to the power of compassion.
Even the kind and benevolent mind of birds and beasts can still bring liberation, let alone the mind that gives rise to good wishes, which will not bring liberation?
Long ago, there was a butcher who wanted to make offerings to a monk, but because of his evil deeds, no one would go.
Later, he saw a newly ordained monk with dignified demeanor and invited him back to his home for a meal with various delicacies. After the meal, he again invited the monk:
Please eat in my home for the rest of your life.
The monk then accepted it.
As he became familiar with the butcher, he often saw him killing living beings, but did not dare to admonish him.
After many years, the butcher's father died and became a river spirit. With his sword, he cut the monk's body and it immediately healed again.
The monk crossed the river, and the ghost grabbed the boat, saying:
Drown this monk in the river and then you can leave.
The boatman was frightened and said:
The ghost said:
I used to make offerings to this monk at home for many years, but he never admonished me for killing living beings. Now I am suffering this misfortune. I am angry and want to do this.
The boatman said:
Even killing still results in this retribution, let alone for a person on the path?
The ghost said:
I know you are angry, that's all!
If you can make offerings and create blessings for me, calling my name and making aspirations, I will let you go.
The boat people all agreed to create blessings for him, and the ghost then released them.
The monk then held a gathering for the ghost, calling his name and making aspirations. The others also held a gathering. They went to the river and called out to the ghost, saying:
Have you received the blessings yet?
The ghost said:
I have received them, and the pain is gone.
The boat people said:
We will create blessings for you tomorrow. Can you come by yourself?
The ghost said:
I can!

The ghost transformed into the appearance of a brahman in the morning and came to make offerings with his own hands. He received the aspirations and the senior monk explained the sutra to him. The ghost then attained the path of stream-entry and joyfully left.

Therefore, the propriety of host and guest has the principle of admonishing and correcting. Even if one falls into the evil realms, there are still good conditions. One can say that a good spiritual friend is a great cause and condition!
(31) In the past, a merchant went to sea to collect treasures. He encountered a great dragon god who raised the ship, wanting to capsize it. The people were terrified.
The dragon said:
Have you ever traveled to that country?
They replied:
We have passed through it before.
The dragon gave him a large egg the size of a five-liter jar:
You should bury this egg under a big tree in the market of that country. If you do not, I will kill you later.
The man agreed.
Later, after passing through that country, he buried the egg under a big tree in the market.
From then on, the country had many calamities, epidemics, and pestilence.
The king of the country summoned the Daoists to perform divination, and they said there was a python egg in the country, causing the calamities and epidemics.
They immediately dug it up and burned it, and the illnesses were all cured.
The merchant who entered the sea later saw the dragon god asking about the situation with respect, and the merchant said:

In the past, as the god instructed, I buried the eggs in the market. There were many illnesses in the country. The king summoned the Brahmins to examine them. It was determined that burning the sick would eliminate the illnesses.
The god said:
I regret not killing the slaves.
The boatmen asked the god:
Why is it so?
The god said:
Have you ever heard of a strong man named so-and-so in a certain country?
They said:
We have heard of him, but he has already passed away!
The god said:
That was me!
When I was alive, I delighted in bullying the people of the country. No one taught me to stop. They only encouraged me, causing me to fall into a python. I want to kill them all!

Therefore, people should admonish each other to follow goodness and be harmonious, not relying on their power to bully others, causing themselves to invite misfortune and suffering in the three evil paths, which can only be heard of and not experienced in person.
Once in the country of Varanasi, there were five hundred blind people who went around begging. They happened to encounter a famine and could not get anything. They discussed among themselves:
The Buddha is in Shravasti teaching people to be generous. We should go to that country and we can get by.
They each said:
We should hire someone to lead us there.
The five hundred blind people each promised to give one silver coin. The man agreed to take them to that country and they set off on their journey.
The hired man said to the blind people:
The road ahead is dangerous. You should each give me your money. If we encounter bandits, I will hide it for you.
The blind people gave him all their money, and the man immediately left with the money.
The blind people wandered for several days, hungry and thirsty, not knowing the way, so they all took refuge in the Buddha at the same time, saying:
The Buddha's divine sageliness should have pity on us and save us from this calamity.
The Buddha suddenly manifested his spirit in front of them, and with his hand he touched the heads of the blind people, all of whom regained their eyesight and were filled with food and drink.
The five hundred people rejoiced and leaped for joy, wishing to become disciples, and their beards and hair fell out, and they were clothed in Dharma robes.
The Buddha again expounded the Dharma for them, and they all attained arhatship and flew with the Buddha back to Jetavana.
Ä€nanda addressed the Buddha, saying:
What offenses and merits did these five hundred people have in their past lives?
The Buddha said:

In a past life, there was an elder who hired five hundred people to work. He first gave them their wages, which they each scattered and left with. Then, they went through many lifetimes experiencing this calamity.
The elder who carried the money away then is now!
When the debt was resolved, he encountered me and was enlightened, and now he has attained the Way.
Thus, the consequences of good and evil are like this. Therefore, the karma created by people is not the same. Some create karma, some experience the consequences of karma. One cannot be careless.
(33) In the past, there were two people who were close friends and did not disagree with each other.
Later, one person committed a crime that should result in death, so he ran away and passed by his friend.
The friend did not open the door and asked:
Who are you?
He replied:
I am your friend. I have committed a crime and have come to pass by you.
The friend said:
When things are easy, we are close friends. When there is danger, each of us should go our own way. I will not let you in.
The friend was very unhappy and thought to himself:
When things are easy, we come and go, eat and drink together without separation. Why do we abandon each other when there is danger?
Is this being sincere?
He then left and wanted to enter the mountains.
There was also a good friend who passed by. The man then opened the door and hid him, saying:
Although you and I are not close, I will send you to a safe place.

He then loaded precious treasures in a cart and personally escorted him to another country. He should inform the king and elders there, build a palace for him, provide him with fields, houses, wealth, and treasures, and then leave.
At that time, the Buddha saw this person and used him as an analogy:
The criminal is analogous to the human spirit;
The close friend is analogous to the four elements of the body;
The good friend is analogous to the Three Refuges and Five Precepts.

It is analogous to a person nurturing the four elements, providing food and drink, and the four things being without lack. When impermanence arrives, one will fall into an evil realm. Seeking to hide in a storehouse, one immediately closes the door and does not go forward.

Later, they encounter a good spiritual friend, who takes them to another country, provides them with what they need, and gives them without lack. It is like giving and upholding precepts. When the body dies, the power of blessings leads them to the heavens, where they reach the palace of the seven treasures, wear heavenly jeweled robes, and naturally obtain the hundred flavors of heaven. The bliss is immeasurable.

Therefore, when a person is born in the world, do not eat and nourish oneself, but should reduce and create blessings. Like nourishing the four elements of the body, how can it be of any benefit? Those who know should practice it!

(34) One hundred years after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a, there was a king who served the gods. He had a great sacrifice using a hundred cows, sheep, pigs, dogs, and chickens. All were given to the cooks to kill the cows and sheep.
Among the cooks, there was an upÄsaka who said:
I uphold the Buddha's precepts and cannot kill living beings.
The cook supervisor became greatly angry and immediately said to the Buddha:
I want to punish him.
The king asked:
Do you still want to disobey my teachings?
I will kill you!
The cook replied:
I am a disciple of the Buddha who upholds the five precepts. Rather than killing myself, I would not violate the Buddha's teachings and then kill living beings.
If I were to follow the king's instructions and commit murder, I would die and enter hell, where I would suffer for millions of years before being released, and would always have a short life.

If I uphold the precepts without defect and am executed by the king, I will be reborn in the heavens after death, where I will receive blessings and have everything I wish for naturally. Even if I were to die now, my current life will be transformed into a heavenly existence. The rewards of sin and merit are far apart.
For this reason, I would rather die than violate the precepts.
The king said:
Give him seven days. We will have an elephant trample him to death. If he does not die, then what he says may be true.

After seven days, the cook became a lay Buddhist, and his body manifested the characteristics of a Buddha's body, resembling the Buddha's form. As a test, five hundred elephants were brought to trample him.

The upÄsaka, like the Buddha, raised his five fingers and transformed them into the five great mountains, between each mountain a lion emerged. When the elephants saw the lions, they were terrified and all lay down on the ground, just as when the Buddha was present.
The king then believed and knew there was a Buddha, so he stopped making sacrifices.
He followed this person in receiving the Buddha's precepts, and the ministers and people also all followed in receiving the precepts, and eventually became the national teacher.
The wise one's upholding of the precepts and saving of people was like this.
(35) In the past, when the Buddha was in the world, there was an upÄsikÄ who went to the Buddha morning and evening to make offerings with utmost sincerity, never slacking off.
The Buddha knew and asked:
What aspirations do you have?
She then said to the Buddha:
If there is any blessed retribution, I wish to be reborn with four sons in this life.
The Buddha then asked:
Why do you seek four sons?
The upÄsikÄ said:ğŸ”½I wish to have four sons to serve the four heavenly kings.

If the four sons grow up, I want one to be in charge of making a living, trading, and accumulating wealth, one to know farming and raising livestock, accumulating the six domestic animals and grains, one to seek official positions and enjoy a salary to provide for the family, and one to leave home and become a monk, attain the Way, and then save their parents and all people. I only seek four sons for this reason!
The Buddha said:
I will let you obtain what you wish.
The upÄsikÄ was overjoyed, bowed to the Buddha, and left.
Later, she gave birth to a son who was intelligent and wise. His mother loved him incomparably in the world.
When the son grew up, he asked his mother:
Why is your love so excessive, unprecedented?
His mother said to her son:
Originally, I wished for four sons, but I only have you, one son. I love you all the more, so it is like this!
She told her son everything she had wished for.
The son, hearing his mother's words, deeply felt his mother's determination, and immediately went to do business. In less than a year, he obtained vast wealth;
Next, he established fields and businesses, raising livestock and occupying marshes. He had countless cattle, horses, grain, and rice;
Next, he went to study and seek official positions, took a wife, had a son, and his family became a wealthy household.
He then said:

The reason I asked for four sons, each knowing one thing, is to take their place. Three things have been mostly accomplished, but there is still one thing lacking. If I can go forth and leave home, it would be excellent.
His kind mother said:
The wishes of the four sons have been fulfilled!
The mother thought to herself:

My original wish was for the four sons to take care of one thing each, but I was still afraid it would not be accomplished. What this son has done exceeds my original expectations. If I allow him to go forth and leave home, he will surely be able to attain the Way.
She then gave her permission for him to leave home.

The son took leave of his mother and went to the Buddha, seeking to become a monk. He immediately attained full vigor and soon attained the path of arhatship. He then saved his parents and all people, and everyone was joyful in attaining blessings and the path.
Therefore, making merit and making vows are only in the mind and will, and there is nothing that cannot be attained.

(36) In the past, there was an old woman who had only one son. He fell ill and died. They carried him to the charnel ground to leave the corpse. She was so grief-stricken that she could not help herself:
I have only one son who should take care of me in my old age, but he abandoned me and died. What is the use of my living?
I cannot return, so I will end my life right here.
She did not eat or drink for four or five days.
The Buddha knew this and went to the charnel ground with five hundred bhikshus.
The old woman saw the Buddha coming from afar, his majestic spirit shining brightly. She became confused and then sobered up. She went to the Buddha, bowed, and stood there.
The Buddha said to the old woman:
Why are you here in the charnel ground?
She said to the World-Honored One:
I have only one child who has passed away. My love for him is deep. I wish to die together with him.
The Buddha told the old woman:
Do you wish for your child to come back to life?
The mother said:
Yes, I do!
He said:
I wish for that!
The Buddha said:
Get some incense and fire. I will chant a vow for him to be reborn.
He told the old woman:
When seeking fire, you should get it from a family where no one has died.
Then the old woman went to get fire. Whenever she saw someone, she would ask:
Have there been any deaths in your family before or after?
They replied:
Everyone in our ancestors has died.
The answers she received at all the places she visited were the same.
After visiting dozens of families, she did not dare to take the fire. She then returned to the Buddha and said to the World-Honored One:
I searched everywhere for fire, but there was no one who had not died. Therefore, I returned empty-handed.
The Buddha told the old woman:
Since the opening of heaven and earth, there is no birth that does not end.
When people die, the living descendants will also be happy.
Why is the mother alone confused and following her son to die?
The mother's mind then became enlightened and recognized the principle of impermanence.

The Buddha then extensively expounded the sutras and Dharma for her, and she attained the path of stream-entry. Thousands of people observing at the grave site gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
(37) In the past, there was a man with two wives.
The elder wife had no children, while the younger wife gave birth to a boy who was upright and lovable. Her husband was very happy.

The elder wife was jealous inside but outwardly pretended to love him more than her own child. When the child was about one year old, everyone in the household knew that the elder wife loved him dearly, and no one doubted it anymore.

The elder wife stabbed the child's forehead with a needle, piercing through the skin and flesh. The child became sick and cried without breastfeeding. No one in the household, young or old, knew the reason. After seven days, the child died.

The elder wife also wept. The younger wife, her thoughts destroyed, wept day and night without stopping. She no longer ate or drank, and her life was hanging by a thread. Later, she found out that it was the elder wife who had harmed her, and she wanted to take revenge.
She went to the monastery and asked the monks:
Virtuous ones, if one wishes to fulfill one's heart's desires, what merits should one cultivate?
The monks replied:
If one wishes to fulfill one's desires, one should uphold the eight precepts of the upavÄsa. One's wishes will be fulfilled.
She then received the eight precepts from the monks and left. Seven days later, she died.
She was reborn as the daughter of the elder wife, and she was beautiful. The elder wife loved her, but she died at the age of one.
The elder wife sat upright and did not eat, her grief and sorrow surpassing that of the younger wife.

In this way, seven times, either two years or three years, or four, five, six, or seven years, later she became more and more beautiful than before. In her last year, at the age of fourteen, she was already engaged to be married. On the eve of her departure, she suddenly died.
